lines.text: You know, you look pretty good for your age.
Thanks, but I'm seeing someone in wrapping.

[in a light-hearted psychiatry tone]
Scott, what was the last thing you and Charlie did, before you went to bed Christmas Eve?

[sarcastically]
We shared a bowl of sugar, did some shots of brown liqour, played with my shot guns, field-dressed a cat, looked for women...
[honestly]
I read him a book!
What book?

[sarcastically]
Uh, "Hollywood Wives."
[Laura puts her hand into her face, giving off a resentful gesture]

[honestly]
"The Night Before Christmas", folks, come on!
[flying away in the sleigh]
Merry Christmas to all, and to all a good night! When I get home, I'm getting a CAT scan!
What about Santa's reindeer? Have you even seen a reindeer fly?
Yes.
Well, I haven't.
Have you ever seen a million dollars?
No.
Just because you can't see something, doesn't mean is doesn't exist.

[yelling out to his ex-wife in her car driving away from his house]
It was a dream! Stuff like that doesn't happen! It was a dream! Come on! I don't even wear pajamas! Normally I sleep naked! BUCK naked! Ha!
[suddenly embarrassed, to a woman walking down his sidewalk]
Good morning, Mrs. McCoy, Mary Katherine.
Eyes front, Mary Katherine.
Sometimes, boxer shorts. You know.
You're fatter this year.
Thank you. You've grown too. Now go back to sleep.
[Drinks the milk and gags a little]
What's wrong?
I think the milk's a little sour.
It's soy milk.
Huh?
You said you were lactose intollerant.
Whoa, Dad! You're flying!
It's okay, I'm used to it. I lived through the '60s.
I'll ship the list to your house.
What list?
You know, the list.
[starts singing]
He's making a list.

[singing loudly]
Checkin' it twice!
Gonna find out who's naughty or nice!

Well, isn't that a pretty picture, Santa rolling down the block in a PANZER! Well kids, I... I certainly hope you have been good this year, cause it looks like Santa just took out the Pearson home. Incoming!
Neil doesn't believe in Santa
Well, Neil's head comes to a point.
Where is he?
Well, he could be listening to records jumping up and down on his bed wearing a red hat and galloshes.
I don't care what Neil's doing. Where's Charlie?
Charlie, stay away from those things. They're reindeer, you don't know where they've been. They all look like they've got key lime disease.
Get the bag of toys.
And do what?
Go down the chimney.
Down the chimney? You want me to take the toys down the chimney into a strange house, IN MY UNDERWEAR?

[after he watches in the mirror as his beard grows back within one second after he shaved it prior to the big custody hearing]
I'm in big trouble. Mm-hmm.
Hey, Barabbas!
Ber-nard!
Bernard, can we take a direct flight back to reality, or do we have to stop and change planes in Denver?
Hey, Charlie, you know how to call 911?
I say 'name', you say 'Scott Calvin'.
[gestures Scott to come close]
Name?
Kris Kringle.
Name?
Sinterklaas.

[annoyed]
Name!
Pere Noel. Babbo Natale. Pelznickel.
[imitates Ed Sullivan]
Topo Gigio!
Okay, Calvin, maybe a couple of hours in the tank will change your mind.
Here's Neil's mother's number.
1-800-SPANK-ME? I know that number.
We're your worst nightmare. Elves with attitude.
I don't know, Scott. You're as healthy as a horse.
Yeah! Clydesdale!
So what? You put on a little weight.
Weight? Does this look like a little weight to you?
Weight can fluctuate from year to year.
Fluctuate? You make it sound like I'm retaining water. I've gained 45 pounds in a week. Pete, what's happening to me?
Well, what's your diet like?
Milk and cookies.
Really?
But I don't finish all the milk.
Well then there is your problem. Just try to cut back on the sweets, okay?
Santa?
Scott Calvin.
Howcome your clothes are so baggy?
Because Santa is... watching his saturated fats.
[gestures obesity]
Howcome you don't have a beard?
Because I shaved!
[instantly reveals an unwrapped present for her, out of his bag]
You want this doll or not? Go back to sleep.
What's all this boo-hooin' going on here?
[to Neil, who suddenly backs away from him]
Hey, how are you doing?
Nothing, Bernard. I'm just saying good-bye to Charlie.
What good-bye? Charlie, you've still got the glass ball I gave you, right?
Yeah.
Well, all you've got to do is shake it, whenever you want to see your dad. He can come back to visit you anytime, day or night.

[his face lights up]
Really?
Hey, have I ever steered you wrong?
Did I miss anything?
No, we were, uh, just about to order lunch.
Great! I'm starving.
I'll have a salad and iced tea, and dressing on the side.
Ah, paste and tomatoes, uh, and very light on the oil. Can you do that?

And I'll have a Caesar. No dressing. And one of those homemade cookies, the warm chocolate chip. No nuts. And a little slice of cheesecake. Uh, crème brulee, and, um, hot fudge sundae, extra hot fudge.
[licks his lips in addiction to tons of sweets, and looks at some people looking weirdly at him]

[taking where he left off]
On the side.
Anything to drink?

[sighs]
Ice-cold milk.

[wondering if he was really honest with them about his suddenly big belly]
Stung by a bee, Scott?
A big bee.
[assuming that he's Santa, sees Scott take celery off of a plate left out for him, but neglect the milk right by it]
You're supposed to drink the milk.
Look, I am lactose intolerant! And I'm just about this close to taking all those presents back up the chimney.
[bites on his celery stick, and under his breath, mocks Sarah]
You're supposed to drink the milk!
[she opens her eyes after hearing what he said]
Shut your eyes!
[she does]
Tinsel. Not just for decoration.
[repeated line]
What if I fall off the roof?
Excuse me. Are we on a coffee break?
We don't drink coffee.
THEN I GUESS THE BREAK IS OVER! Back to work. Thanks.

[explaining her hot cocoa recipe]
Not too hot. Extra chocolate. Shaken, not stirred.
I don't know what's happening to you. You're starting to look like the Pillsbury Doughboy.
All Neil told him was that Santa was more of a feeling. More of a state of mind than an actual person.
Kind of like Neil.
Charlie, I'm sorry I didn't believe you.
That's okay, Neil. You were just denying your inner child.
You're going to make a great psychiatrist someday, kid.
Nah. I think that I'm going to go into the family business.
Neil's a really good cook.
Yeah, and you should see him walk on water.
You don't like him very much, do you, Dad?
Charlie, I'm sorry, I was just kidding around around. Sure I like him. But there's just something about him that makes me want to -...
Lash out irrationally?
Now, where did you hear that?
From Neil. I learn a lot from him. He listens to me.
Yeah! And he charges you for it.
Not necessarily. It could be rude, sarcastic, whatever it takes!
These are Santa's reindeer, aren't they?
I hope not. These are... A gift. Probably from the cable company. We're getting the Disney Channel now. Merry Christmas.
Dad?
What is it, Charlie?
Maybe you better leave some milk and cookies out, just in case. Okay?
Great. I'll just go pre-heat the oven.
And don't forget the fire extinguisher!
Good night, Charlie!
Johnny, naughty. Gary, nice.
[Sees a beautiful woman]
Veronica, very nice.
In your dreams, sleigh boy.

[to fallen Santa Claus]
Fella, if you can hear me, I'm just looking for your identification. As soon as I find out who you are, I'll give you a lift back to the mall.
Good God, your weight! What happened?
Bee sting. Evidently I'm allergic. It almost killed me. But, the guy at the Emergency Room said that eventually the swelling will go down. I hope.

In putting on the suit and entering the sleigh, the wearer waives any and all right to any previous identity, real or implied, and fully accepts the duties and responsibilities of Santa Claus, in perpetuity to which some time the wearer becomes unable to do so, by either accident or design.
What does that mean?
If you put on the suit, you're the big guy.
This is ridiculous! I didn't just put on the suit to -...
Try to understand this!
Why not? What if don't buy any of this Santa Clause thing? What if I choose not to believe it?
[a dead silence falls upon the workshop]

Then there would be millions of disappointed children around the world. You see, children hold the spirit of Christmas within their hearts. You don't wanna be responsible for killing the spirit of Christmas, now would you... Santa?

[looks at Neil's sweater]
Nice sweater. Hey, did we make this?
[starts checking the tag on the sweater]
Yeah, well, look at my hair. It's turning grey.
Oh, it's middle age, buddy. It happens. And with that body, you should be thankful you have hair. Look, if it bothers you, you can dye it - and you should diet!
It's Santa! You killed him!
Did not! And he's not Santa!
Well, he was...
The only thing you need to worry about is where you're going to buy your sweaters after the circus pulls out of town.

[about what will happen for Christmas Eve dinner]
Are you going to your mom's for dinner.
Actually, we're going with Neil's family.
Ah, Christmas at the pound!
[mockingly imitates a howling wolf, a hissing cat, and a cat meowing]
Woa, how did you do that? How did that feel Dad?
It felt like America's Most Wanted.

[he bag lifts him up]
Hey, hey, HEY, wait, there is no chimminy here okay, no chimminy.
Lookin good Dad.

[hovers over a thin pipe]
You have got to be kidding me.

[to a dog growling and baring its teeth at him]
Nice teeth.
Whoa! This could be a really long night.
Do it again Dad, please?

[picks up the bag]
I can't the things empty

[Comet the reindeer gets angry and growls]
There nothing in the bag. Even if there was, did you notice there is no chimney? Where there's no chimney, there's no fireplace.

[Comet growls]
Are you growling at me?

[Comet nods his head]
Look, comet, like I said there is nothing left...
Look, I am not Santa Claus! Ahhh!
Did you or did you not read the card?
Yeah, I read the card.
Then you're the new Santa. And putting on their hat and jacket, you accepted the contract
What contract?
The card in the Santa suit, you said you read it, right? So when you put on the suit, you fell subject for the Santa Clause.
The Santa Claus? Oh, you mean the guys that fell off my roof?
No, no, not Santa Claus, the person. Santa Clause the clause.
What?
You're a businessman right? Okay, a clause as in the last line of the contract.

[Scott looks confused]
You got the card? Okay look.
[Reads what the I.D. card says]
What does that mean?
It means you put on the suit, you're the big guy.
That ridiculous, I didn't put on a suit to...

[shouts]
*Try to understand this!*

In putting on this suit and entering the sleigh, the wearer waives any and all rights to any previous identity, real or implied, and fully accepts the duties and responsibilities of Santa Claus, in perpetuity until such time that the wearer becomes unable to do so, by either accident or design.
My dad is Santa Clause.

[reading the fallen Santa's instruction card]
If something should happen to me, put on my suit; the reindeer will know what to do.

[after Santa has fallen off of the roof]
Look, Dad, he disappeared.

[looks around]
He's naked somewhere.
Seeing isn't believing. Believing is seeing.
You should see a doctor, a shrink, a dietician, anything.
Here we are. Denny's. Always open.
I don't wanna eat here.
What are you talking about? Everybody likes Denny's, it's an American institution.
This thing, you never know where it's been. A thousand malls! Well I hope you're happy, Comet. I hope you're happy, but most importantly, I hope the guy that lives here IS A TAILOR!
Who gave you permission to tell Charlie there was no Santa Claus? I think if we're going to destroy our son's delusions, I should be a part of it.
You said you believe in Santa Claus, right, Dad?
I did? I do!

[on the phone with his ex-wife while driving on an empty road, making up an excuse for his tardiness to meeting her and their son]
I ran real late today. You wouldn't BELIEVE the traffic out here.
[honks his horn, and pretends to yell out to the street]
Hey, same to you! And that's not very ladylike!
[back to his wife]
three car pile-up. I'm really gonna be late.
Hey, kid, kid... who's in charge here?
You are, and I'm not a kid, I have pointy SHOES that are older than you... I'm an elf.
Hey, I know where this is going. The other guy fell, it was an accident. I've got homeowners insurance, and a good attorney, not as good as my wife's - but lets not open up that wound!

[as he tosses the snow globe to Scott]
Remember!

[about Neil]
I learn a lot from him. He listens to me.
Yeah, then he charges you for it.
It is Santa! You killed him!
Did not! And that's not Santa!
Well, he was.
Can we take a direct flight back to reality, or do we have to change planes in Denver?
Haven't you people ever heard about basting?
Raindeer up on the roof... Santa suit laying on the ground... Guy fell... not my fault... Raindeer on the roof... THAT is hard to explain...
It's the ladder.
[Scott turns and bumps into the ladder]

[referring to ladder]
Where the hell this come from?

[when the E.L.F.S. arrive to the police station to bust out Santa]
Go home, kids. Visiting hours are over.
We're not kids, and we're not visiting.
You know... the list.

[singing quietly]
He's making a list...

[singing loudly]
Checking it twice!

[singing loudly in unison]
He's gonna find out who's naughty or nice!
[Bernard groans; exasperated]

[to his father, Scott]
I'm fine, Dad. Think about those kids! You're Santa! We were up in the North Pole!
Charile... I don't know.
What do you mean you don't know?
Charlie... listen...
YOU listen! You think you know what he is... You *DON'T*!
Charlie... You're confused.
I know exactly who he is.

[firmly]
Charile... HE is NOT Santa!

[whining; desperate]
HE IS TOO SANTA! We went up to the North Pole. I saw it! We met the Head Elf, Bernard. He knew everything!
[turns to Scott]
Right Dad?
[Scott looks unsure]

[tossing him the snow globe Bernard gave him]
REMEMBER!
